coredata.dc:title: Ethylidyne formation rates on the Pt(111) surface
coredata.dc:creator: Gland, John L.
Zaera, Francisco
Fischer, Daniel A.
Carr, Roger G.
Kollin, Edward B.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The isothermal rates of ethylidyne formation from adsorbed ethylene have been characterized on a Pt(111) surface from 230 to 280 K using transient near edge X-ray absorption fine structure (T-NEXAFS). These studies establish the feasibility of T-NEXAFS as a method for measuring surface reaction rates in the 10−2 to 10−5 monolayer/s range. Since direct measurements of surface concentrations are used to establish the rates of the surface reaction no desorbing products are required for characterization of the isothermal reaction rates. The ethylidyne formation rates are first order in ethylene coverage. A substantial isotope effect is observed, perhydroethylene reacts about twice as fast as perdeuteroethylene. The activation energies are 14.4±0.7 kcal/mol (perhydro) and 16.7±1.0 kcal/mol (perdeutero) for the alehydrogenation of adsorbed ethylene.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 151, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 14 October 1988 ETHYLIDYNE FORMATION RATES ON THE Pt(ll1) SURFACE John L. GLAND a~ Francisco ZAERA b, Daniel A. FTSCHER ~ Roger G. CARR d and Edward B. KOLLIN a Corporate Resea.rch Laboratory, Exxon Research and Engineering, Clinton Township, Annandale, NJ 08801, USA ~ Chemistry Department, University of flhtfornia Riverside, Riverside, CA 92521, USA Exxon P.RT. NSLS Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton. NY 1)973. USA d SS RL, StanJbrd Linear Accelerator Center, Stanjbrd, CA 94305, USA Received 11 July 1988 The isothermal rates of ethylidyne formation from adsorbed ethylene have been characterized ana Pt 1,1 11) surface from 230 to 280 K using transient near edge X-ray absorption fine structure (T-NEXAFS). These studies establish the feasibility of T- NEXAFS as a method far measuring surface reaction rates in the 10_2 to I 0 ~ monolayer/s range. Since direct measurements of surface concentrations are used to establish the rates of the surface reaction no desorbsng products are required for characteriza- tion of the isothermal reaction rates. The ethylidyne formation rates are first order in ethylene coverage. A substantial isotope effect is observed, perhydroethylene reacts about twice as fast as perdessteroethylene. The activation energies are 14.4 0.7 heal / mol (perhydro) and 16.7 1.0 kcal/mnl (perdeutero) for the dehydrogenation of adsorbed ethylene. Ethylene adsorption and dehydrogenation have been studied extensively on the Pt( Ill) surface us- ing a wide range of surface methods [1 61. The ini- tial work which lead to structural characterization of ethylidyne has recently been summarized [1]. More recent articles have focused on further spectroscopie and kinetic characterization of ethylene and ethyli- dyne [2 9]. NEXAFS spectra of ethylene and ethy- lidyne on Pt (111) clearly indicate that these species can be distinguished easily [10]. The surface char- acterization methods agree that ethylene adsorbs with its C C bond parallel to the surface. In the 295 K temperature range ethylene losses a single hydrogen atom and rearranges to form adsorbed ethylidyne C CH3. This transformation occurs in a temperature range where hydrogen desorption is not rapid; thus measurements of gas phase hydrogen formation rates may not accurately reflect the rate of ethylene de- hydrogenation [Il]. In this Letter we report isothermal NEXAFS mea- surements of cthytidyne formation rates on the Pt (111) surface. Rates were obtained by measuring the concentration of adsorbed ethylidyne using NEXAFS. Previous kinetic studies have been pri- marily based on the desorption rate of hydrogen from the surface [2 9]. Recently isothermal secondary ion mass spectrometry (SIMS) studies of ethylidyne for- mation have been reported by Ogle et al. as part of a SIMS study of adsorbed ethylene and ethylidyne [9]. They observed an activation energy of 15 kcal/ mol and a fairly complex coverage dependence of the rate. The NEXAFS experiments were performed at beamline l-l of the Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory. This beamline is equipped with a grass- hopper monochromator as described previously [12]. We ran with a resolution of about 0.7 eV at 300 eV and estimate the photon flux on the sample tobe approximately I X l0~ photons/s for a ring cur- rent of 50 mA. The end station contained provisions for TPD, low energy electron diffraction, Auger elec- tron spectroscopy and gas dosing. The Pt( ill) sam- ple was oriented, prepared and cleaned using standard procedures. Soft X-ray absorption was measured using a partial electron yield detector based on a 5 cm diameter channel plate located approxi- mately 5 cm from the sample. A retarding potential of 200 eV was used for collection of spectra above the carbon K edge. NEXAFS spectra of adsorbed ethylene and ethyl- 227 Volume 151, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 14 October 1988 Photon Energy (ev) Fig. 1. NEXAFS spectra of ethylene (T=90 K) and elhylidyne (T= 300 K) ehemisorbed on the P5(111) surface taken with the incident light normal to the surface. The difference between the spectra is also shown to indicate the maximum at 285.8 eV used In measure the surface concentration of ethylidyne. 0 250 500 Time (seconds) Fig. 2. A typical data set oblained during ethylidyne formation from perdeuteroethylene adsorbed on the Pt (111) surface. The photon energy was fixed at 285.8 eV and normal incidence was used. The temperature was rapidly increased from 130 to 264 K at zero time to initiate the reaction. 250 500 Times (s) Fig. 3. The linear semilogarithmie plots of the log of ethylene sur- face concentration versus time indicate that ethylidyue forma- tion is first order in ethylene surface concentration. t o u o C, C ci (n 8.5 8.25 8.0 e,D4 Decomposition Pt(III) SAA&M&&JS hr I I t I I j idyne agree with earlier results as illustrated in fig. 1 [10]. The concentration of adsorbed ethylidyne was determined using the intensity of ethylidyne s it~ resonance at 285.8 eV. A typical kinetic result is shown in fig. 2 for perdeuteroethylene dehydrogen- ation at 264 K. Ethylidyne formation begins im- mediately as the sample is heated to reaction temperature as indicated by the abrupt rise in inten- sity at zero time. The background signal at 285.8 eV ts about 8>< l0~ counts/s (c/s) while a saturated monolayer of ethylidyne yields an additional 2.5 X 102 c/s giving a signal-to-background of about 3%. Each data point represents a 10 s average. The absolute noise level is close to being statistical (below 25 c/s for 10 s counting time per point), so the signal to noise is better than 10%. Thus kinetic, measure- ments can certainly be performed for starting aver- ages as small as 10% of saturation coverage. Semilogarithmic plots of ethylene coverage as a function of time for several temperatures in the 230 C o CL es w-n, ce t>- t, 0. t c SD o-te .~ e S>- zt e w to 280 K range are illustrated in fig. 3. These linear plots clearly indicate that the reaction is first order in ethylene coverage. Small non-linearities near the stan of the kinetic experiments are caused by tem- perature fluctuations associated with the tempera- ture step which initiated the experiment. An Arrhenius plot of the ethylidyne formation rates from perhydro and perdentero ethylene is shown in fig. 4. Perhydroethylene dehydrogenates about twice as rapidly as perdeuteroethylene. The activation ener- gies for ethylidyne formation are 14.4 0.7 (per- hydro) and 16.7 1.0 kcal/mol (perdeutero). The e e s. C o C o e Di e e s o C, e C s s. w 1.0 0.5 0.2 ETHYLENE CONVERSION TO ETHYLIDYNE Pt (111) SL C2H4 Te=170K Eh, 285.8 eV dt n - 252K 258K 211K 228 Volume 151, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 14 October 1988 ~0 C o c, e t e o. t~C e o o C a E e u o, o L4x l0~~ preexponential factor for perhydroethy- lene is smaller than the 3.9>< 10 preexponential ob- served for perdeuteroethylene indicating that a compensation effect is observed for the ethylidyne formation reaction. The first-order behavior in ethylene surface cov- erage clearly indicates that a single ethylene mole- cule is involved in the rate limiting step. The isotope effect observed is consistent with a primary isotope effect, suggesting that C H bond cleavage may be in- volved in the rate limiting step. The first-order be- havior in ethylene coverage is quite different from the complex coverage dependence observed using SIMS. This comparison suggests that neutralization effects may be causing non-linearities in the re- sponse of the SIMS signal as a function of coverage [9]. In summary, transient electron yield NEXAFS is a promising method for characterizing the rates of surface reactions, particularly when rapid product desorption does not occur. Ethylidyne formation on the Pt (Ill) surface is first order in ethylene cov- erage indicating a single ethylene molecule is in- volved in the rate limiting step. A substantial isotope effect is observed indicating that hydrogen is in- volved in the rate limiting step. References [1] H. Ihach and D. The first-order behavior in ethylene surface cov- erage clearly indicates that a single ethylene mole- cule is involved in the rate limiting step. The isotope effect observed is consistent with a primary isotope effect, suggesting that C H bond cleavage may be in- volved in the rate limiting step. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The isothermal rates of ethylidyne formation from adsorbed ethylene have been characterized on a Pt(111) surface from 230 to 280 K using transient near edge X-ray absorption fine structure (T-NEXAFS). These studies establish the feasibility of T-NEXAFS as a method for measuring surface reaction rates in the 10−2 to 10−5 monolayer/s range. Since direct measurements of surface concentrations are used to establish the rates of the surface reaction no desorbing products are required for characterization of the isothermal reaction rates. The ethylidyne formation rates are first order in ethylene coverage. A substantial isotope effect is observed, perhydroethylene reacts about twice as fast as perdeuteroethylene. The activation energies are 14.4±0.7 kcal/mol (perhydro) and 16.7±1.0 kcal/mol (perdeutero) for the alehydrogenation of adsorbed ethylene.
